Award.AwardTitle: Using Science to Build Tribal Capacity for Data-Intensive Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The federal government has a trust responsibility to tribal nations that is implemented through federal statutes and programs intended to promote economic self-sufficiency and the distinct sovereign status of tribal nations and their people. Quality, tribal-level data is essential for ensuring the federal trust and for informing the work of tribal leaders to strengthen their governments. Within this broader context, this project will improve tribal data quality and capacity for data-intensive research by building a data network of tribes, social scientists and federal policymakers; assisting with ongoing tribal data collection designed to improve the reliability, validity, and long-term sustainability of tribal data; and by using the Census Bureau?s Research Data Centers to provide tribes with data better aligned to tribal boundaries and tribal needs. The broader impacts of this work are far reaching and include: 1) Improved data collection and analyses to assist tribes to better meet the needs of the Native populations they serve; 2) Strengthened tribal data infrastructure so that comparative analyses can be developed and policy based on more than individual tribal cases; 3) New insights for social science research about American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) demographic characteristics through real-world data experiences of tribes; 4) Solutions to data security and confidentiality issues facing tribal governments; and 5) Insights for emerging international conversations about data linkage and Indigenous identification in large data sets, amongst others.

The United States boasts unmatched scientific capacity, but it has long failed to provide even the most basic enumeration of AI/AN people. Despite thorough documentation that this population is at great risk of poverty and the problems that flow from poverty, detailed information about labor force participation, social service needs, educational attainment, and related information is sparse and unreliable. Enumeration issues involve those related to indicator fit for tribal populations, those related to generating appropriate geographic boundaries for tribal data, and those related to the actual collection of tribal data for measurement purposes. This project is designed to address enumeration issues using a participatory approach to research. It explores the question of how to improve the quality of tribal-level data collection, reporting, and management to assist tribal leaders, federal policymakers, and social scientists. The project will utilize multiple methods, including qualitative data collection and analysis through interviews and focus groups, quantitative analysis of secondary data collected from the Census Bureau?s Research Data Centers and from, and survey data collection by partner tribes. The goal is to produce a range of tools and resources to improve tribal-level data collection and use, including a survey template that could be used by tribal nations and federal agencies like the Census Bureau and the Department of the Interior to supplement existing person-level data collection from American Indian and Alaska Native people.

Institution.Name: National Congress of American Indians Fund

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using Science to Build Tribal Capacity for Data-Intensive Research

Project Outcomes Report

 

Project Summary

The aims of this project were to build a community committed to the collection and dissemination of data on American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) populations, assist ongoing data collection by individual tribes, and to review selected tribal data collection topics to generate recommendations to improve and promote new data collection efforts by tribal nations. Project activities included a survey of tribal data capacity and practices, a review of the time tribes spend on meeting federal reporting requirements, a review of the use of tribal service area geographies and populations by federal agencies and programs, and technical assistance and pilot grant funding to tribes to conduct their own censuses and surveys. The work of the project resulted in four monographs that described the work of this project:

- NCAI Policy Research Center (2018). The State of Tribal Data Capacity in Indian Country: Key Findings from the Survey of Tribal Data Practices. Washington, DC: National Congress of American Indians.

- NCAI Policy Research Center (2017). Recommendations from Tribal Experiences with Tribal Censuses and Surveys. Washington, DC: National Congress of American Indians.

- NCAI Policy Research Center (2017). Meeting the Reporting Requirements of Federal Agencies. Washington, DC: National Congress of American Indians.

- NCAI Policy Research Center (2017). The Geospatial Dimensions of Tribal Data. Washington, DC: National Congress of American Indians.

The work of this project was disseminated during NCAI and other tribal conferences, through webinar presentations, and the products were disseminated through social media, email broadcasts, and the project webpage.

Intellectual Merit

This project helps advance the field of knowledge around tribal data capacity and provides important new information for researchers, tribal leaders, and program administrators working on issues relevant to AI/AN communities. Increasing tribal data capacity helps improve the quality and outcomes of research which helps advance science and better community outcomes.

Broader Impact

This project will have broad impact on research conducted with communities facing health and other disparities. Advancing knowledge about tribal data capacity helps researchers and program leaders understand similar issues in small populations and other diverse communities where building data capacity can help address challenges and concerns of those communities in a culturally appropriate and community engaged manner.
